Canonical joint distribution of Z-score and B-values under null and alternative hypothesis

Yujie Zhao, Yilong Zhang, and Keaven M. Anderson

Source: vignettes/articles/story-canonical-h0-h1.Rmd
story-canonical-h0-h1.Rmd

When applying the AHR test in the time-to-event endpoint at the kk-th analysis, we build the standardized treatment effect as the test statistics in Proschan, Lan, and Wittes (2006):

Zk=∑i=1dkΔiVar(∑i=1dkΔi|H0), Z_k = \frac{ \sum_{i=1}^{d_k} \Delta_i }{ \sqrt{\text{Var}(\sum_{i=1}^{d_k} \Delta_i | H_0)} },

where dkd_k is the total number of events at analysis kk. Here, Δi=Oi−Ei\Delta_i = O_i - E_i with OiO_i is the indicator that the ii-th event occurred in the experimental arm, and Ei=mi,1/(mi,0+mi,1)E_i = m_{i,1}/(m_{i,0} + m_{i,1}) as the null expectation of OiO_i given mi,0m_{i,0} and mi,1m_{i,1}. The numbers mi,0m_{i,0} and mi,1m_{i,1} refer to the number of at-risk subjects prior to the ii-th death in the control and experimental group, respectively. When conditioning on mi,0m_{i,0} and mi,1m_{i,1}, the OiO_i has a Bernoulli distribution with parameter EiE_i. So the null conditional mean and variance of Δi\Delta_i are 0 and Vi=Ei(1−Ei)V_i = E_i(1 - E_i), respectively. Unconditionally, Δi\Delta_i are mean 0 random variables with variance E(Vi)E(V_i) under the null hypothesis. So, conditioned on dkd_k, we have Var(∑i=1dkΔi|H0))=E(∑i=1dkVi\text{Var}(\sum_{i=1}^{d_k} \Delta_i | H_0)) = E(\sum_{i=1}^{d_k} V_i).

In this vignette, we discuss the statistical information. Mathematically, it is the inverse of the variance, depending on whether it is under null or alternative hypothesis:

ℐk,H0=1/Var(∑i=1dkΔi|H0),ℐk,H1=1/Var(∑i=1dkΔi|H1). \begin{array}{c} \mathcal I_{k, H_0} = 1 /\text{Var}(\sum_{i=1}^{d_k} \Delta_i | H_0), \\ \mathcal I_{k, H_1} = 1 /\text{Var}(\sum_{i=1}^{d_k} \Delta_i | H_1). \end{array}

The ratio between two statistical information under the null hypothesis is called information fraction:

tk=Var(∑i=1dkΔi|H0)Var(∑i=1dKΔi|H0)≈dk/4dK/4=dk/dK, t_k = \frac{\text{Var}(\sum_{i=1}^{d_k} \Delta_i | H_0)}{\text{Var}(\sum_{i=1}^{d_K} \Delta_i | H_0)} \approx \frac{d_k/4}{d_K / 4} = d_k /d_K,

In the rest of this vignette, we will discuss the value of ℐk,H0,ℐk,H1\mathcal I_{k, H_0}, \mathcal I_{k, H_1}. To derive these statistical information, we introduce the B-values:

Bk=∑i=1dkΔiVar(∑i=1dKΔi|H0)=∑i=1dkΔiVar(∑i=1dkΔi|H0)⏟ZkVar(∑i=1dkΔi|H0)Var(∑i=1dKΔi|H0)⏟tk=tkZk, B_k = \frac{ \sum_{i=1}^{d_k} \Delta_i }{ \sqrt{\text{Var}(\sum_{i=1}^{d_K} \Delta_i | H_0)} } = \underbrace{ \frac{ \sum_{i=1}^{d_k} \Delta_i }{ \sqrt{\text{Var}(\sum_{i=1}^{d_k} \Delta_i | H_0)} } }_{Z_k} \underbrace{ \frac{ \sqrt{\text{Var}(\sum_{i=1}^{d_k} \Delta_i | H_0)} }{ \sqrt{\text{Var}(\sum_{i=1}^{d_K} \Delta_i | H_0)} } }_{\sqrt{t_k}} = \sqrt{t_k} Z_k,

As depicted in Section 2.1.3 of Proschan, Lan, and Wittes (2006), the stochastic process formulation presented in Harrington, Fleming, and Green (1984) and Tsiatis (1982) provides insights that sequence of B-values, denoted as B1,…,BK{B_1, \ldots, B_K} with follows a multivariate normal distribution behaves asymptotically like Brownian motion.

For 2 B-values (Bi,BjB_i, B_j with i≤ji \leq j), we have

Cov(Bi,Bj)=Cov(∑s=1diΔsVar(∑s=1dKΔs|H0),∑s=1djΔsVar(∑s=1dKΔs|H0))=1Var(∑s=1dKΔs|H0)Cov(∑s=1diΔs,∑s=1djΔs)=1Var(∑s=1dKΔs|H0)Cov(∑s=1diΔs,∑s=1diΔs+∑s=1djΔs−∑s=1diΔs)=1Var(∑s=1dKΔs|H0)Var(∑s=1diΔs)+Cov(∑s=1diΔs,∑s=1djΔs−∑s=1diΔs)=1Var(∑s=1dKΔs|H0)Var(∑s=1diΔs) \begin{eqnarray} \text{Cov}(B_i, B_j) & = & \text{Cov} \left( \frac{ \sum_{s=1}^{d_i} \Delta_s }{ \sqrt{\text{Var}(\sum_{s=1}^{d_K} \Delta_s | H_0)} }, \frac{ \sum_{s=1}^{d_j} \Delta_s }{ \sqrt{\text{Var}(\sum_{s=1}^{d_K} \Delta_s | H_0)} } \right) \\ & = & \frac{1}{\text{Var}(\sum_{s=1}^{d_K} \Delta_s | H_0)} \text{Cov} \left( \sum_{s=1}^{d_i} \Delta_s, \sum_{s=1}^{d_j} \Delta_s \right) \\ & = & \frac{1}{\text{Var}(\sum_{s=1}^{d_K} \Delta_s | H_0)} \text{Cov} \left( \sum_{s=1}^{d_i} \Delta_s, \sum_{s=1}^{d_i} \Delta_s + \sum_{s=1}^{d_j} \Delta_s - \sum_{s=1}^{d_i} \Delta_s \right) \\ & = & \frac{1}{\text{Var}(\sum_{s=1}^{d_K} \Delta_s | H_0)} \text{Var} \left( \sum_{s=1}^{d_i} \Delta_s \right) + \text{Cov} \left( \sum_{s=1}^{d_i} \Delta_s, \sum_{s=1}^{d_j} \Delta_s - \sum_{s=1}^{d_i} \Delta_s \right) \\ & = & \frac{1}{\text{Var}(\sum_{s=1}^{d_K} \Delta_s | H_0)} \text{Var} \left( \sum_{s=1}^{d_i} \Delta_s \right) \end{eqnarray}

Null hypothesis

The distribution of {Bk}k=1,…,K\{B_k\}_{k = 1, \ldots, K} has the following structure:

  • B1,B2,…,BKB_1, B_2, \ldots, B_K have a multivariate normal distribution.
  • E(Bk|H0)=0E(B_k \;|\; H_0) = 0 for any k=1,…,Kk = 1, \ldots, K.
  • Var(Bk|H0)=tk\text{Var}(B_k \;|\; H_0) = t_k.
  • Cov(Bi,Bj|H0)=ti\text{Cov}(B_i, B_j \;|\; H_0) = t_i for any 1≤i≤j≤K1 \leq i \leq j \leq K.

The derivation of the last 2 statement is

Var(Bk|H0)=Var(∑i=1dkΔi|H0)Var(∑i=1dKΔi|H0)=tkCov(Bi,Bj|H0)=1Var(∑s=1dKΔs|H0)Var(∑s=1diΔs|H0)=ti \begin{eqnarray} \text{Var}(B_k\;|\; H_0) & = & \frac{ \text{Var}(\sum_{i=1}^{d_k} \Delta_i | H_0) }{ \text{Var}(\sum_{i=1}^{d_K} \Delta_i | H_0) } = t_k\\ \text{Cov}(B_i, B_j \;|\; H_0) & = & \frac{1}{\text{Var}(\sum_{s=1}^{d_K} \Delta_s\;|\; H_0)} \text{Var} \left( \sum_{s=1}^{d_i} \Delta_s\;|\; H_0 \right) = t_i \end{eqnarray}

Accordingly, {Zk}k=1,…,K\{Z_k\}_{k = 1, \ldots, K} has the canonical joint distribution with the following properties:

  • Z1,Z2,…,ZKZ_1, Z_2, \ldots, Z_K have a multivariate normal distribution.
  • E(Zk|H0)=0E(Z_k \;|\; H_0) = 0.
  • Var(Zk|H0)=1\text{Var}(Z_k \;|\; H_0) = 1.
  • Cov(Zi,Zj|H0)=ti/tj\text{Cov}(Z_i, Z_j \;|\; H_0) = \sqrt{t_i/t_j} for any 1≤i≤j≤K1 \leq i \leq j \leq K.

Alternative hypothesis

Under the alternative hypothesis, for 2 B-values (Bi,BjB_i, B_j with i≤ji \leq j), the distribution of {Bk}k=1,…,K\{B_k\}_{k = 1, \ldots, K} has the following structure:

  • B1,B2,…,BKB_1, B_2, \ldots, B_K have a multivariate normal distribution.
  • E(Bk|H1)=θktkℐk,H0E(B_k \;|\; H_1) = \theta_k t_k \sqrt{\mathcal I_{k, H_0}} for any k=1,…,Kk = 1, \ldots, K.
  • Var(Bk|H1)=tkℐk,H0/ℐk,H1\text{Var}(B_k \;|\; H_1) = t_k \mathcal I_{k, H_0} / \mathcal I_{k, H_1}.
  • Cov(Bi,Bj|H1)=tiℐi,H0/ℐi,H1\text{Cov}(B_i, B_j \;|\; H_1) = t_i \; \mathcal I_{i, H_0}/\mathcal I_{i, H_1} for any 1≤i≤j≤K1 \leq i \leq j \leq K.

The last statement is derived as

Cov(Bi,Bj|H1)=1Var(∑s=1dKΔs|H0)Var(∑s=1diΔs|H1)=1Var(∑s=1dKΔs|H0)Var(∑s=1diΔs|H0)⏟tiVar(∑s=1diΔs|H1)⏟1/ℐi,H1/Var(∑s=1diΔs|H0)⏟1/ℐi,H0=tiℐi,H0/ℐi,H1. \begin{eqnarray} \text{Cov}(B_i, B_j \;|\; H_1) & = & \frac{1}{\text{Var}(\sum_{s=1}^{d_K} \Delta_s | H_0)} \text{Var} \left( \sum_{s=1}^{d_i} \Delta_s | H_1 \right) \\ & = & \underbrace{ \frac{1}{\text{Var}(\sum_{s=1}^{d_K} \Delta_s | H_0)} \text{Var} \left( \sum_{s=1}^{d_i} \Delta_s | H_0 \right) }_{t_i} \underbrace{ \text{Var} \left( \sum_{s=1}^{d_i} \Delta_s | H_1 \right) }_{1/\mathcal I_{i, H_1}} \bigg/ \underbrace{ \text{Var} \left( \sum_{s=1}^{d_i} \Delta_s | H_0 \right) }_{1/\mathcal I_{i, H_0}} \\ & = & t_i\; \mathcal I_{i, H_0}/\mathcal I_{i, H_1}. \end{eqnarray}

Accordingly, ZkZ_k has the canonical joint distribution with the following properties:

  • Z1,Z2,…,ZKZ_1, Z_2, \ldots, Z_K have a multivariate normal distribution.
  • E(Zk|H1)=θkℐk,H0E(Z_k \;|\; H_1) = \theta_k \sqrt{\mathcal I_{k, H_0}} with the treatment effect as θk\theta_k at the kk-th analysis.
  • Var(Zk|H1)=ℐk,H0/ℐk,H1\text{Var}(Z_k \;|\; H_1) = \mathcal I_{k, H_0} / \mathcal I_{k, H_1}.
  • Cov(Zi,Zj|H1)=titjℐi,H0ℐi,H1\text{Cov}(Z_i, Z_j \;|\; H_1) = \sqrt{\frac{t_i}{t_j}} \frac{\mathcal I_{i, H_0}}{\mathcal I_{i, H_1}} for any 1≤i≤j≤K1 \leq i \leq j \leq K.

The last statement is because

Cov(Zi,Zj|H1)=Cov(Bi/ti,Bj/tj)=1titjCov(Bi,Bj)=1titjVar(Bi)=titjℐi,H0ℐi,H1 \begin{eqnarray} \text{Cov}(Z_i, Z_j \;|\; H_1) & = & \text{Cov}(B_i/\sqrt{t_i}, B_j/\sqrt{t_j}) \\ & = & \frac{1}{\sqrt{t_i t_j}} \text{Cov}(B_i, B_j) \\ & = & \frac{1}{\sqrt{t_i t_j}} \text{Var}(B_i) \\ & = & \sqrt{\frac{t_i}{t_j}} \frac{\mathcal I_{i, H_0}}{\mathcal I_{i, H_1}} \end{eqnarray}

When the local alternative assumption holds, we have Cov(Zi,Zj)≈titj\text{Cov}(Z_i, Z_j) \approx \sqrt{\frac{t_i}{t_j}}, which is in the format of the canonical joint distribution introduced in Chapter 3 of Proschan, Lan, and Wittes (2006).

Summary

B-value Z-score
Expectation mean at the kk-th analysis under H0H_0 0 0
Expectation mean at the kk-th analysis under H1H_1 θktkℐk,H0\theta_k t_k \sqrt{\mathcal I_{k, H_0}} θkℐk,H0\theta_k \sqrt{\mathcal I_{k, H_0}}
Variance at the kk-th analysis under H0H_0 tkt_k 1
Variance at the kk-th analysis under H1H_1 tkℐk,H0/ℐk,H1t_k \mathcal I_{k, H_0} / \mathcal I_{k, H_1} ℐk,H0/ℐk,H1\mathcal I_{k, H_0} / \mathcal I_{k, H_1}
Covariance between the ii-th and jjth analysis under H0H_0 (i≤ji\leq j) tit_i ti/tj\sqrt{t_i/t_j}
Covariance between the ii-th and jjth analysis under H1H_1 (i≤ji\leq j) tiℐi,H0/ℐi,H1t_i \; \mathcal I_{i, H_0}/\mathcal I_{i, H_1} titjℐi,H0ℐi,H1\sqrt{\frac{t_i}{t_j}} \frac{\mathcal I_{i, H_0}}{\mathcal I_{i, H_1}}

References

Harrington, DP, TR Fleming, and SJ Green. 1984. “Procedures for Serial Testing in Censored Survival Data.” In Strukturen Und Prozesse Neue Ansätze in Der Biometrie: 28. Biometrisches Kolloquium Der Biometrischen Gesellschaft Aachen, 16.–19. März 1982 Proceedings, 124–38. Springer.
Proschan, Michael A., K. K. Gordon Lan, and Janet Turk Wittes. 2006. Statistical Monitoring of Clinical Trials: A Unified Approach. New York, NY: Springer.
Tsiatis, Anastasios A. 1982. “Group Sequential Methods for Survival Analysis with Staggered Entry.” Lecture Notes-Monograph Series 2: 257–68.
